Article.ArticleTitle: NO<sub>x</sub> emission trends over Chinese cities estimated from OMI observations during 2005 to 2015.

AbstractText: Satellite NO<sub>2</sub> observations have been widely used to evaluate emission changes. To determine trends in NO<sub>x</sub> emission over China, we used a method independent of chemical transport models to quantify the NO<sub>x</sub> emissions from 48 cities and 7 power plants over China, on the basis of Ozone Monitoring Instrument (OMI) NO<sub>2</sub> observations during 2005 to 2015. We found that NO<sub>x</sub> emissions over 48 Chinese cities increased by 52% from 2005 to 2011 and decreased by 21% from 2011 to 2015. The decrease since 2011 could be mainly attributed to emission control measures in power sector; while cities with different dominant emission sources (i.e. power, industrial and transportation sectors) showed variable emission decline timelines that corresponded to the schedules for emission control in different sectors. The time series of the derived NO<sub>x</sub> emissions was consistent with the bottom-up emission inventories for all power plants (r=0.8 on average), but not for some cities (r=0.4 on average). The lack of consistency observed for cities was most probably due to the high uncertainty of bottom-up urban emissions used in this study, which were derived from downscaling the regional-based emission data to cities by using spatial distribution proxies.
